fields.main_plant_environment: Pretty much everywhere.  Whether it be wasteland or gardens.  Country lanes and pathways.
fields.culinary_uses: Nettle pesto is tasty. Boil the nettle tops for a few minutes and then whizz with olive oil, garlic, grated Parmesan or other hard Italian cheese – salt to taste. Pine nuts or other nuts can also be added. Eat with pasta in the traditional way.
fields.medicinal_uses:
Nettles, known for their anti-inflammatory properties, they've been used to treat arthritis and muscle aches.
Some people even use them fresh purposely utilizing their stinging qualities to stimulate the skin as pain relief.
fields.history_and_folklore: Nettle has long been recognized for its bounty of nutrition as well as its sting. Folk medicine and lore worldwide attributes the powers of protection and fertility to this incredible plant. Wisdom handed down from ancient times includes advice on using nettle to protect one’s self from lightning, to enhance fertility particularly in men, to reduce the swelling of arthritic joints, to heal the sick and bestow courage on those who carry it as well as how to avoid being stung by nettle. In Kawaiisu tribal practice as in Celtic lore, nettle serves as a threshold guardian. Nettle fibres have been found in burial cloths from the Bronze age, also closely linking this plant with the threshold between life and death, and giving credence to the various folklore bits that describe Nettle as growing from or near the dead.
fields.main_plant_parts_used:
Nettle seeds grow in tiny geometric clusters on thin threads along the stem, after the plant has flowered. Check out our Instagram Reel which may help identify them!  When Nettles go to flower, all the energy and goodness goes into producing the flower and seeds, and the leaves go all tough and stringy, you’ll notice they don’t look quite so vibrant! At this point, we stop picking the leaves, and turn our attentions towards foraging for nettle seeds.
As the plant is dioecious, only half the plants will carry the seeds (the female). The male plants produce pollen to fertilise the female, which in turn produces the seeds. The female plants are distinguished by their slightly frosty appearance and droopiness of the flowers. Both plants are edible, but when it comes to harvesting the seeds, make sure you pick from female plants as their seeds are full of nutritional goodness.
You know the seeds are ready to pick when the long seed bundles droop towards the stem. We would generally recommend picking from the top ⅓ of the plant, where the seeds and nutrients are most abundant, also leaving plenty of opportunity for  regrowth and the plant’s survival.
fields.main_plant_warnings: Other than being mindful of the time of year that you pick nettles.  The one continuous things to be mindful of is that they have an awful sting to them. There's a knack to picking them.  A firm grip with the finger and the thumb and an upward motion.  But all said and done...  You could just wear gloves instead.
fields.confusable_plant_name: Dead Nettles. Looks just like Stinging Nettles but there's no sting!
fields.confusable_plant_information: Dead Nettles consists of 30 or so species. Flowers colors from Dead Nettles are yellow, purple/pink, and white which bare the closest resemblance to Stinging Nettle leaves.
fields.confusable_plant_warnings: Unlike the Stinging nettles being targeted, all the Dead Nettles are considered safe.  So, if it doesn't sting you, then it's not the right one!

fields.main_plant_environment: Being less prone to frosts coastal areas hold most of theses unusual plants, so in order to find Alexanders, it is said that you need to be within 15 - 20 miles of the coast (or in an area that isn’t prone to frost). That being said, I have found them a long way in land. Hedge banks and roadsides seem to be the most common place to find this unusual plant. Once you know how to identify this plant, you will see it everywhere.
fields.culinary_uses:
The leaves can be used in salads or cooked – Roman Parsley suggests that the Romans did indeed use it as a herb for seasoning their foods. The flowers can be pickled or used in a salad and the root (if you can get permission) can be treated the same as Parsnip. The stalk is where you will find the most value! The thick stems near the bottom of the plant are best.
It’s as good a green as any other, containing vitamin C and fibre. The little black fruits are particularly tasty and when dried make an interesting alternative to peppercorns. You can use the leaves like spinach and the stalk like a celery. I like to put in my green goddess soup. It adds a slightly floral coriander-ish flavour and is also great in stir-fries.
fields.medicinal_uses:
Alexanders was a traditional plant for cleansing the blood and a digestive herb for strengthening the stomach.
Seafarers used it to treat scurvy and herbalists used it to relieve stomach and urinary problems.
fields.history_and_folklore: Another plant that was apparently brought over by the Romans to be used as a pot herb. It’s fast growing and a great source of fibber. I’ve been told the reasons it’s Latin name is ‘smyrnium’ is because it smells like myrrh
fields.main_plant_parts_used: Leaves, stalks at the start of spring through to June for it's flowers and finally, it's seeds in the fall.  It's root's anytime of the years, but always get the land owners permission to dig up anything!
fields.main_plant_warnings: When young, Alexanders look similar to the highly poisonous Hemlock water dropwort a.k.a dead man’s fingers.  This is an extremely dangerous one to get wrong.
fields.confusable_plant_name: Hemlock water dropwort a.k.a dead man’s fingers
fields.confusable_plant_information: Bright green and shiny, a bit fern like with two to four pinnate divisions, the whole looking triangular in shape.
fields.confusable_plant_warnings:
"Extremely poisonous!
The most poisonous plant in the UK and very common along most of our waterways!
Part of the carrot family which several highly poisonous species like hemlock and hemlock water-dropwort.
No forager, novice or other wise takes the carrot family for granted."

fields.main_plant_environment: Pesto, Soups, Stirred into Pasta dishes and stir-fries.  You can dry the leaves and eat them like crisps or simply chop them up into an Omelette!
fields.culinary_uses: The juice from ramsons when squeezed would be used as a household disinfectant, whilst the pungent aroma was useful for keeping the midges away.
fields.medicinal_uses: The juice from ramsons when squeezed would be used as a household disinfectant, whilst the pungent aroma was useful for keeping the midges away.
fields.history_and_folklore:
Wild Garlic has a rich history and folklore dating back centuries. It is native to Europe and Asia and has been used for medicinal and culinary purposes since ancient times. In folklore, wild garlic was believed to have protective properties and was used to ward off evil spirits and vampires. It was also believed to be a symbol of strength and courage and was often used by soldiers before battle.
In some cultures, wild garlic was associated with fertility and was used to promote sexual potency.
fields.main_plant_parts_used: Initially the leaves. But as the season continues, the flower buds, the flowers and eventually the seed pods
fields.main_plant_warnings: The biggest danger with Ramsons is that you may ostracise friends who don't like garlic
fields.confusable_plant_information:
Growing a month or so later, the new leaves can be mistaken for Ramsons. One people should be aware of as it can be fatal if eaten.
Key thing to note, this plant does not smell of garlic.
fields.confusable_plant_warnings: Contains "Cardiac Glycosides" similar to "foxgloves", causing nausea, vomiting, blurry vision, and disruption to the heartbeat that can be fatal.

fields.main_plant_environment: Pretty much any land that has been left to nature
fields.culinary_uses: Dock leaves can be eaten raw or cooked. But leave it too long and the leaves can be bitter and come with certain provisions.  The stems can be eaten raw or blanched, tasting like broad beans, sauteed in butter! Better yet, pickle it!  As the plant flowers and seeds, the seed can be harvested and treated as buckwheat.
fields.medicinal_uses: High in Iron as a food source, believed to help skin irritations and aids digestion.
fields.history_and_folklore: Traditionally, people believed that stings or skin irritation from stinging nettles could be soothed by rubbing dock leaves on the affected area. This was often seen as nature's remedy, particularly since dock leaves commonly grew near nettles, as if nature was providing a natural balance. In reality, the dock leaf mainly gave some relief by cooling the skin, giving the person something to focus on while the sting gradually subsided.
fields.main_plant_parts_used: Leaves and Seeds as the season goes by.
fields.main_plant_warnings:
"Eaten raw in small amounts is generally considered safe, more so with young leaves.  But much like many other plants, the leaves contain ""Oxalic Acid"" which can be toxic when ingested in large amounts.  Cooking reduces the amount of Oxalic Acid.
"
fields.confusable_plant_information: Easy to mistaken, but it's no hardship. Many would happily take it home instead.
fields.confusable_plant_warnings: Back breaking to dig out from the ground

fields.main_plant_environment: Woodland, hedgerows, waste ground and often cascading over walls and fences into gardens where they're not wanted.
fields.culinary_uses: The new shoots can be a nibbled snack on country walks or gathered to add to a salad, not too many, mind. For later in the year, the Blackberries that the plants produce are ideal for pies and jams!
fields.medicinal_uses: Containing tannins, the leaves and bark of bramble was used as an astringent to treat dysentery and diarrhoea.
fields.history_and_folklore: According to folklore, when the devil was cast out from heaven by St Michael, he landed in a bramble bush and put a curse upon it so that the fruits would taste bitter and not worth picking as the season ended. This coincided with St Michael’s Day – after which they should not be taken.
fields.main_plant_parts_used:
"In spring the new shoots, still soft, flexible and thorn free as a trail snack or taken back home for the salad bowl.
Later in the year as the fruits mature, eaten freshly picked from the bushes or picked for jams and preserves"
fields.main_plant_warnings: If using the fruits later in the year, be mindful of the thorns that scratch your arms and stems that will trip you as you walk, gathering the fruits.

fields.culinary_uses: Lamb’s lettuce or corn salad is a leafy green vegetable with a nutty flavour, commonly cultivated in France but less commonly found in shops. In the wild it grows as a weed of cereal crops thus the name corn salad
fields.medicinal_uses: Rich in beta-carotene that is turned into vitamin A. Rich in Iron and vitamin C.
fields.history_and_folklore: Lamb's lettuce is sometimes called "corn salad" because it used to grow with corn in fields. The name "lamb's lettuce" refers to the leaves' resemblance to lamb's tongues.

fields.main_plant_environment: Fields and hedgerows, often used as naturally growing fences
fields.culinary_uses: The young leaves, flower buds and young flowers are all edible. They can be added to green salads and grated root salads. The developing flower buds are particularly good. The haws can be eaten raw but may cause mild stomach upset.
fields.medicinal_uses: Young leaf shoots, flowers and the berries known as "haws", traditionally and right up to modern day. The berries are known to support heart health, circulation, and lowering blood pressure.
fields.history_and_folklore: Considered to be a magical enchanted tree, and is associated with Beltane, celebrating spring. In Celtic mythology it is one of the most sacred trees and symbolizing love. Believed to have fairies who live under the tree, protecting it.  The sprigs of leaves and flowers often worn in the headdresses of brides.
fields.main_plant_parts_used: Young leaves, flowers and the berries
fields.main_plant_warnings: Same as many other fruits which include apples, pears and cherries, they're members of the rose family and contain small amounts of compounds that turn into cyanide when metabolised through the process of digestion.

fields.main_plant_environment: Grows in large tiers on the trunk and stumps of Oak,  Cherry, Sweet Chestnut, Willow and Yew.
fields.culinary_uses: Great in stews and casseroles in place of chicken, stir fries or marinated in a satay sauce and skewered.  Always must be cooked.
fields.medicinal_uses: Ongoing studying of the antioxidant compounds and long-chained sugars called "polysaccharides" that seem to encourage the immune system.
fields.history_and_folklore: In European folklore, Chicken of the Woods (often referred to as COTW) was believed to have magical powers and was thought to protect the trees it grew on from other harmful fungi. In reality, it is parasitic and causes decay in its host trees. This protective role in folklore likely stemmed from its flamboyant appearance, with bright orange and yellow hues standing out among the darker forest colors. The reason other parasitic fungi were unlikely to be found on the same tree was due to the speed at which COTW could colonize its host.
fields.main_plant_parts_used: Entire fruiting body, which is best when young otherwise it becomes very woody.
fields.main_plant_warnings:
If gathered from Yew trees, it's important that when cutting it away from the wood, none of the yew be taken as Yew is poisonous. This includes any stray Yew tree needles that can often get imbedded in this fast growing polypore.

Even when not gathered from Yew trees, this fungus can cause upset stomachs for some. So it's important to start with just a little to check for tolerance.

Never eat it without cooking!

fields.main_plant_environment: A common tree that's found in woodland, parks and gardens across the UK
fields.culinary_uses: Rowan berries make wonderful jellies and sauces. Always needing to be cooked, otherwise they're toxic and can cause very upset tummies.
fields.medicinal_uses: Rich in Vitamin C, considered a remedy for sore throats when made into a syrup and have laxative properties.
fields.history_and_folklore: In European folklore, Rowan trees were seen as powerful protectors against evil spirits, witches, and bad luck, often planted near homes and graveyards. In Celtic and Norse traditions, they symbolized protection, transformation, and were linked to magic and the "Otherworld". Their red berries were thought to represent vitality and fire, while Rowan twigs were used in divination rituals used to protect travellers from danger and fairy mischief!
fields.main_plant_parts_used: Flesh of the berries, separating the seeds which are discarded.
fields.main_plant_warnings: Same as many other fruits which include apples, pears and cherries, they're members of the rose family and contain small amounts of compounds that turn into cyanide when metabolised through the process of digestion.

fields.main_plant_environment: Hedgerows and forest edges, preferring slight shade.
fields.culinary_uses: As lovely a treat as these are, there's never enough to take home.  But as a small snack on a summer's day, their taste out do their cultivated cousins!
fields.medicinal_uses:
Laxative and diuretic: The leaves of the wild strawberry plant have mild astringent properties and can be used as a laxative and diuretic. 
A tea made from dried wild strawberry leaves can help with kidney and stomach issues. 
During the American Revolution, Minutemen drank a tea made from wild strawberry leaves to prevent scurvy.
fields.history_and_folklore: "Strawberry Patch", a metaphor for nostalgic times or cherished memories, famously referenced by The Beatles in their song "Strawberry Fields Forever".

fields.main_plant_environment: Woodland, Parks and very common in Cemeteries.
fields.culinary_uses:
The berries from the Yew tree are more of a trail snack, but the determined forager could gather sufficient to make a conserve.
Other than the flesh of the berry, EVERY PART of the Yew tree is toxic, so the berries MUST be spat out!
fields.medicinal_uses: As with many toxic substances, the Yew, when used in small amounts and properly handled, has been utilized in medicine, even up to the present day. Most notably, it led to the development of a drug called Paclitaxel, marketed under the name Taxol, which is used as a chemotherapy treatment for cancer
fields.history_and_folklore:
The Yew tree holds deep significance in folklore. Symbolizing death, rebirth, and eternity due to how long the trees live and their evergreen nature. Often found in graveyards, it was believed to protect the dead and guide souls to the afterlife.

It's wood, strong yet flexible, was prized for making English longbows that were capable of shooting long distances.
fields.main_plant_parts_used: Only the flesh of the berries, always spitting out the seeds.  Failing to do this can be fatal!
fields.main_plant_warnings: Other than the flesh of the berries, all parts of the Yew are toxic and even swallowing the seeds that are in the berries can be fatal.

fields.title: Spring Wild Edibles"
fields.description: Explore the bounties of spring in the beautiful Ashdown Forest. This course introduces participants to the vibrant world of wild edibles that emerge after winter. Learn to identify and safely harvest plants like wild garlic, nettles, and chickweed, and discover their culinary uses. Guided by experienced foragers, you’ll gain hands-on experience in sustainable foraging practices, plant identification, and seasonal recipes that celebrate the fresh flavors of spring.

fields.title: Foraging Fundamentals: A Spring Workshop
fields.description: Uncover the basics of spring foraging in the serene South Downs National Park. Perfect for beginners, this workshop covers essential foraging skills, plant safety, and sustainability tips. Participants will identify spring greens, herbs, and flowers, learning how to prepare them in simple yet delicious dishes. Whether you’re a nature lover or a food enthusiast, this hands-on course provides a perfect introduction to the art of foraging.

fields.title: Coastal Foraging Adventure
fields.description: Discover the treasures of the coastline in this immersive foraging course. Learn to identify and harvest edible seaweeds, shellfish, and coastal plants while exploring the stunning Jurassic Coast. Led by expert foragers, you’ll gain insights into the unique ecosystems of the shore, sustainable harvesting techniques, and culinary tips for turning your finds into delicious meals.

fields.title: Mid-Summer Hedgerow Harvest
fields.description: Celebrate the abundance of summer with this hedgerow foraging course in the lush New Forest. Participants will identify berries, flowers, and herbs at their peak, learning to create syrups, teas, and preserves. This course emphasizes safe foraging techniques and the joy of using nature’s pantry to create seasonal treats.

fields.title: Autumn Foraging and Fungi Exploration
fields.description: Autumn is a forager’s paradise, and this course dives into the rich array of wild foods and fungi found in the Forest of Dean. Participants will identify and harvest mushrooms, nuts, and berries, while learning how to prepare and store their finds. The course also includes tips on distinguishing edible fungi from poisonous varieties, ensuring a safe and enjoyable experience.

fields.title: Seasonal Hedgerow Delights
fields.description: Experience the colors and flavors of autumn in this guided foraging walk through Kew Gardens. Learn to identify and use autumnal hedgerow bounty such as rosehips, hawthorn berries, and sloes. This course combines practical foraging with insights into the nutritional and medicinal benefits of your harvest, concluding with recipes to enjoy at home.
